channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Survivor Tells of Mediterranean Sea Disaster That May Have Killed 500 Migrants
item.description: Flung into the water, Muaz Mahmud said he saw his wife and child, who were out of his reach, drown along with hundreds of others who were also on board.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Obama Urges Britain to Remain in the E.U.
item.media:description: President Obama arrived at London’s Stansted Airport on Thursday.
item.description: In an opinion article coinciding with his arrival in London, the president said that Britain was stronger as a European Union member.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: A Shakespeare Anniversary Brings Pomp and Plays to Stratford-Upon-Avon
item.media:description: A woman opened a curtain during the press preview of the exhibition “Shakespeare in Ten Acts” at the British Library in London last week.
item.description: In the birthplace of William Shakespeare, where he is also buried, festivities are planned to commemorate the 400th anniversary of his death.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Virgin Mary Statue, Intact Among Ecuador’s Quake Ruins, Becomes a Beacon of Hope
item.media:description: An outdoor Mass in Montecristi, Ecuador, on Wednesday. The steeple of the town’s basilica collapsed in the recent earthquake and church leaders decided that it would be too dangerous to hold services inside.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Residents of Montecristi say the survival of the centuries-old Our Mother of Monserrate, even as the basilica cracked and crumbled around it, is a miracle.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Brazil’s Vice President, Unpopular and Under Scrutiny, Prepares to Lead
item.media:description: Police officers guarded the home of Vice President Michel Temer in São Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday. Demonstrators had written “coup headquarters” in the street.
item.description: Vice President Michel Temer, himself linked to a graft scandal, says he is not conspiring to take over as President Dilma Rousseff faces a possible trial.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Europe Says U.S. Regulations Keeping It From Trade With Iran
item.media:description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy, left, met with Ayatollah Ali Khameinei, the Iranian supreme leader, to discuss trade between Iran and the European Union.
item.description: European leaders say restrictions imposed by Washington, even after landmark nuclear agreement, are effectively keeping Iran shut off as a potential trade partner.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Israel Names Palestinian as Bomber in Jerusalem Bus Attack
item.media:description: A poster in Bethlehem in the West Bank on Thursday depicted Abdul-Hamid Abu Srour, 19, left, who Israeli officials said blew up a bus in Jerusalem on Monday.
item.description: The attack on the bus on Monday, the first in Jerusalem in years, revived for many Israelis the memory of the second Palestinian uprising, which began in 2000.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Kurds and Syrian Forces Clash, Adding Wrinkle to War
item.description: Kurdish militias and President Bashar al-Assad’s forces tend to avoid clashes, but skirmished Thursday in the de facto Kurdish autonomous region.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: President Idriss Déby of Chad, in Power Since 1990, Wins 5th Term
item.media:description: President Idriss Déby of Chad at the presidential palace in Ndjamena on Wednesday.
item.description: Mr. Déby, who earned 61.5 percent of the vote, will remain leader of a country that is central to Africa’s fight against Islamic militants.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 6 Pakistani Army Officers, Linked to Corruption, Are Dismissed
item.description: The purge was seen as a signal to Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif that since the military was coming clean on wrongdoing, he should, too.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: North Korea Proposes Having 13 Defectors to the South Meet With Relatives
item.media:description: The Chinese and North Korean flags hang outside a shuttered Korean restaurant in Ningbo, China. Thirteen North Korean restaurant workers are said to have defected to the South this month, although Pyongyang says they were abducted.
item.description: Seoul dismissed the offer as propaganda, reiterating that the 12 waitresses and a male manager from a restaurant run by the North Korean government in China had left of their own free will.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s ‘Dangerous Love’ Campaign, Warning of Spies, Is Met With Shrugs
item.media:description: On a platform in the Dongdan subway station in Beijing, commuters ignore a poster for China’s first National Security Education Day, warning Chinese to beware of foreign spies.
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times
item.description: Posters around Beijing are warning young women that handsome foreigners wooing them may be spies, but many seem unconvinced.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Liao Yiwu on ‘Love in the Time of Mao’
item.media:description: The Chinese writer Liao Yiwu, in Brussels in 2013.
item.media:credit: Colin Delfosse for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Liao discusses his family’s experiences under Mao Zedong and how his novel, to be published later this year in Chinese and English, came about.
item.dc:creator: LUO SILING
item.category: Love in the Time of Mao (Book)

item.title: Bike Path, Heralded as Olympic Legacy, Collapses in Brazil
item.description: The accident on the Tim Maia bike path was the latest in a series of problems that are troubling preparations for the August games.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Venezuela Officially Adopts Electricity Blackouts
item.description: The step formalized the outages that people have already been experiencing during a worsening energy crisis.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: South Sudan Peace Talks Imperiled by New Squabbles
item.description: The arrival of the opposition leader, Riek Machar, in the capital was delayed by a dispute over how many weapons and soldiers could accompany him.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Apple No Longer Immune to China’s Scrutiny of U.S. Tech Firms
item.media:description: An Apple Store in Beijing. Facing a slowdown in sales of iPhones in the United States, Apple is looking to China for growth.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: In an about-face, regulators shut down Apple’s iBooks Store and iTunes Movies six months after they were started in China.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and JANE PERLEZ
item.category: State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television (China)

item.title: Mike Duffy, a Canadian Senator, Is Cleared of 31 Corruption Charges
item.media:description: Mike Duffy, a member of Canada’s Senate, leaving the courthouse after being cleared of bribery and fraud charges in Ottawa on Thursday.
item.description: Mr. Duffy is free of criminal charges, but several other senators have admitted that the trial has further battered the group’s reputation.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Iran Accuses U.S. of Theft in $2 Billion Court Ruling for Terror Victims
item.description: Iran said the United States Supreme Court ruling, which ordered Iran’s central bank to pay nearly $2 billion to victims of terrorist attacks, was amounted to thievery.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Volkswagen Reaches Deal in U.S. Over Emissions Scandal
item.media:description: Joyce Ertel Hulbert, who owns a 2015 Volkswagen diesel, outside the federal courthouse in San Francisco Thursday.
item.description: Owners of hundreds of thousands of diesel vehicles in the United States will be eligible to have their vehicles bought back or fixed.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Paris Journal: A Canopy Where Les Halles Once Reigned Gets Parisian Welcome
item.media:description: La Canopée has risen on the site of Les Halles, the storied market in Paris that was demolished in 1971.
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.description: La Canopée, rising at the site of the storied market that Paris demolished in 1971, is greeted with resignation, relief and lamentation for what is no longer there.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Damien Hirst’s Art May Have Leaked Formaldehyde Fumes, Study Says
item.media:description: Damien Hirst’s sculpture, “The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living” (1991), at Tate Modern in 2012. He is known for works displaying sharks and other animals suspended in formaldehyde.
item.description: The British artist is known for works that displayed animals suspended in the carcinogenic compound, but they may have exposed visitors or staff members.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA

item.title: Leaders Roll Up Sleeves on Climate, but Experts Say Plans Don’t Pack a Wallop
item.media:description: An iceberg in the western Antarctic peninsula. The great ice sheets on the continent are starting to melt.
item.description: Unless countries develop more ambitious plans, they say, the world could suffer profound consequences, including debilitating heat waves, food shortages and fast-rising seas.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS and CORAL DAVENPORT
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Obama Reassures Persian Gulf Allies About Security
item.description: The president ended a meeting in Saudi Arabia with the leaders of six Persian Gulf nations after talks on the American commitment to the region amid a rapprochement with Iran.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s President, Xi Jinping, Gains a New Title: Commander in Chief
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping, center front, at the Central Military Commission’s joint battle command center in Beijing on Wednesday.
item.description: The title reflects the president’s desire to have a more direct role over the armed forces, a professor said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Vancouver Prescriptions for Addicts Gain Attention as Heroin and Opioid Use Rises
item.media:description: Dave Napio, 55, at a single-room occupancy hotel after receiving one of his three daily drug doses at the Crosstown Clinic in Vancouver, British Columbia.
item.description: Treatment known as heroin maintenance has helped keep users out of jail and away from emergency rooms, but concerns about drug abuse stymie such programs in the United States.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Behind Mitsubishi’s Faked Data, Fierce Competition
item.media:description: Tetsuro Aikawa, Mitsubishi’s president, said the company had used the faulty testing method on a number of models.
item.description: The latest automaker scandal has focused attention on the company’s struggles in the brutally competitive Japanese microcar market.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Toll in Blast at Pemex Plant in Mexico Rises to 13; Workers Missing
item.description: Ten more bodies have been found in the wake of Wednesday’s explosion at a petrochemical facility in the state of Veracruz, and 18 employees remain unaccounted for.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In Ecuador, Political Aftershocks
item.media:description: Rescue workers search for survivors in Portoviejo, Ecuador.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: With the country reeling from a devastating earthquake, the most effective relief efforts have come from citizens, not the government.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN PALLARES

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Brexit’s Threat to ‘the Special Relationship’
item.description: The great trans-Atlantic alliance was premised on Britain’s commitment to European unity.
item.dc:creator: STROBE TALBOTT

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Obama in Saudi Arabia, Exporter of Oil and Bigotry
item.media:description: Saudi Shiite women at a protest in January after the execution of a prominent Shiite cleric, Nimr al-Nimr, by Saudi authorities.
item.description: The Islamophobia festering in the U.S. is fed by extremism fostered by the Saudis.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: Dispatch from Dakar: ‘Where Is This Flight Going?’ and Other Basic Questions About African Travel
item.media:description: A moldy airplane on the runway in Cameroon.
item.description: In West Africa, getting there is way more than half the battle.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
